item.title: Last Epoch Developer Eleventh Hour Games Acquired by Krafton
item.content:encoded:
Eleventh Hour Games, the developer and publisher of hack-and-slash action RPG Last Epoch, has announced that it's been acquired by PUBG publisher Krafton for an undisclosed sum.

In an announcement on the official Last Epoch forum, Eleventh Hour founder Judd Cobler, also known as moxjet200, says Krafton was the right choice for his studio because the publisher "shares [Eleventh Hour's] passion for the ARPG genre".

Cobler says the partnership between Eleventh Hour and Krafton will give his studio "the opportunity and resources to execute on [its] goal of creating the very best ARPG in the genre", which is a lofty goal indeed given just how much competition there is in the space.

According to Cobler, he spoke to "dozens of strategics and potential partners" before settling on Krafton, having decided that the partnership will guide Eleventh Hour through "some of the largest upcoming challenges [it will] face as a studio".

This is far from the first acquisition Krafton has made in recent years. Back in August last year, the publisher acquired Tango Gameworks and its Hi-Fi Rush IP following its shutdown at the hands of Microsoft (which, in retrospect, would seemingly prove to be the start of a pattern for the tech giant).

Prior to that, Krafton snapped up The Ascent studio Neon Giant in 2022, which itself followed the purchase of Subnautica developer Unknown Worlds the year prior.

The latter would prove to be a somewhat poisoned chalice for Krafton; earlier this month, the publisher fired the former heads and founders of Unknown Worlds, prompting a lawsuit in which said founders alleged their ousting (and Subnautica 2's delay) was part of a plot to avoid paying employees a sizable bonus.

If you're wondering exactly how Krafton's acquisition will affect Eleventh Hour, well, Cobler says it won't, really. He says his studio will remain a subsidiary under Krafton and won't be merged into the publisher; in fact, new staff will be hired soon, apparently.

In any case, if you'd like to check out Last Epoch, you can do so right now on PC via Steam, where it'll cost you $34.99 or your regional equivalent.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Trails Beyond the Horizon Scores January 2026 Release Date
item.content:encoded:
Trails Beyond the Horizon, the latest game in the long-running JRPG series' Calvard arc, has finally received a Western release date, and it won't be too long before you can check this one out.

As revealed in a brand new trailer, Trails Beyond the Horizon (or, to give it its full title, The Legend of Heroes: Trails Beyond the Horizon) will be arriving across PC, PlayStation, and Nintendo Switch consoles on January 15th.

The game will follow on from the previous titles in the Calvard arc, namely Trails through Daybreak and its sequel. You'll play as three protagonists with intertwining stories: Trails of Cold Steel's Rean Schwarzer, Daybreak's Van Arkride, and Trails in the Sky the 3rd's Kevin Graham.

Trails Beyond the Horizon takes place at the dawn of mankind's "first foray into space", as Nihon Falcom tells it. Rean, Kevin, and Van are drawn into intrigue when Marduk invites them to "co-operate in a high-tech training exercise", setting them on a "collision course with the secrets that lay at the very core of Zemuria".

The game will feature an adapted and enhanced version of Trails through Daybreak's battle system, allowing you to swap between the action-based Field Battle mode and the more strategic Command Battle system.

New features include the ability to slow time with the Z.O.C. system, boosting your damage and allowing for devastating chain attacks, as well as new Shard Commands to grant your party "a range of benefits during battle".

You can check out the release date trailer for Trails Beyond the Horizon right here. It gives a sense of what you can expect from the game's climactic narrative.

The Legend of Heroes: Trails Beyond the Horizon arrives for PC, PlayStation, and both Nintendo Switch and Switch 2 on January 15th, and if you're not caught up yet, be sure to check out our guide on how to get into the series!

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Dying Light: The Beast Delayed for "Extra Polishing"
item.content:encoded:
Developer and publisher Techland has announced that upcoming zombie sandbox parkour-'em-up Dying Light: The Beast has been delayed by a few weeks in order to ensure additional polish.

While the game was originally intended to launch on August 22nd, Techland now says it needs extra time "to make Dying Light: The Beast the best Dying Light game [it's] ever released", which is why the latest title in the series will now be launching on September 19th.

Techland says it understands the delay "may be disappointing", but that its "experience has shown how important the first impression is", and that four extra weeks of development will help the studio "address final details that make all the difference between good and great".

Areas that Techland will be working on between now and the new September release date include gameplay balance, "clarity of UI", physics quality, and animation tweaking, as well as the addition of "last little details".

Additionally, Techland will be releasing more information about Dying Light: The Beast regularly until September, so if you're disappointed you won't be able to play the game in August, the new reveals should tide you over.

If you're unfamiliar with Dying Light: The Beast, it's a standalone followup to 2022's Dying Light 2: Stay Human in which you'll once again take on the mantle of Kyle Crane, the protagonist of the original Dying Light.

The game was originally intended to be a DLC expansion for Dying Light 2, but after plot details for that DLC were leaked by hackers in 2023, Techland decided to turn The Beast into a full standalone followup instead.

You'll be able to check out Dying Light: The Beast when it launches on September 19th for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. You can take a look at our preview here, and make sure to check out our interview with franchise director Tymon Smektala to learn more about the game!
